intro: Quercus robur var. pedunculata, commonly known as the pedunculate oak, is a variant of the common oak native to Europe. It is characterized by its broad, lobed leaves that turn yellow in autumn and its distinctive acorns with a short stalk. The tree typically grows to a height of 20–30 meters, with a broad, spreading crown. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in mixed forests. This variety is valued for its ecological importance and historical significance in European landscapes.
